newsitem.title: UK: London gold fixes barely up in quiet business.
newsitem.headline: London gold fixes barely up in quiet business.

text.p: Gold prices were hovering on fresh 3-1/4 year lows on Tuesday despite recovering slightly around midday, dealers said.
Business levels in New York and Europe were light at the afternoon fixing but sufficient to sustain prices above the day's lows which were met early.
Gold was fixed at $343.40 per ounce, 25 cents above the morning fix which was a fresh low since the September 14, 1993 of $342.05.
Dealers said overnight selling in New York and the Far East was prompted by the continuing strong dollar and profit taking after Monday and Tuesday's short-covering rise.
"It is still under pressure. The sentiment is still bearish and the overall downtrend is still intact," a dealer said. "The very strong dollar isn't helping gold either," he added.
The dealer said that physical support from Hong Kong and Singapore had diminished slightly ahead of the Lunar New Year holidays which will close Hong Kong until February 10.
Hitherto physical support had been prominent. The buying was seen as long term investment interest which would not come back into the market for a 10 or 20 percent profit, dealers said.
Dealers saidthe US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) policy advisory group which begins its second and final day of debate on the domestic economy today was neutral.

A poll by Reuters of U.S. economists showed most of them did not expect a rise in the fed funds rate at the end of the meeting. But a majority of the sample forecast a 25-basis point rise on the fed fund rate of 5.25 percent some time this year.
The steady policy assumption was based on the absence of inflationary pressures but above-trend growth and some labour market tightness hinted at a possible rise later.
More pressingly, the market was still uncomfortable about the possibility of further central bank selling.

"Whether it has happened or not, it is adding to the bearish tone," a dealer said referring to a spike in lease rates and heavy sales last Thursday which were immediately interpreted as the work of the central banks.
The other metals were little changed from morning levels and generally below their previous close.
Platinum was down $2.50 at $351.25/$352.25 and palladium off $1.70 at $126.50/$127.50, both reflecting the sector's weakness.
Silver was a cent down at $4.86/$4.88 amid sparse interest after light early buying.
